repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: 
    When piping raw manpage content into :Man!, the buffer name is set to 'man://.. ref'. However, the existing check  only verifies whether the buffer name starts with 'man://', rather than checking for an exact match.
    `if not fn.bufname('%'):match('man://') then -- Avoid duplicate buffers, E95.`
    This allows :Man! to attempt creating a buffer with a already in use name, triggering E95: Buffer with this name already exists.

Solution:
    Instead of matching just the 'man://' prefix, the new logic checks for an exact match of the buffer name. If the buffer already exists, a unique name is assigned using the format:  `man://<ref>_copy` and `man://<ref>_copy_copy...`, for continuous calls.
    The solution preserves the previous behavior while supporting the creation of multiple buffers with the same man page contents.

Testing:

- Verified that opening a new manpage works as expected.
- Tested piping raw content into :Man!, ensuring no duplicate buffer errors occur.
- Ensured that multiple calls to :Man! create uniquely named buffers (_copy suffix).
- Added test coverage for the newly implemented behavior.

Fix #30132

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  it('raw manpage into (:Man!) creates a new buffer #30132', function ()
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -228,6 +228,25 @@ describe(':Man', function()
     matches('quit works!!', fn.system(args, { 'manpage contents' }))
   end)
 
+  it('Raw manpage into (:Man!) will create new buffer #30132', function ()

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  elseif not fn.bufname('%'):match('man://') then -- Avoid duplicate buffers, E95.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -639,8 +639,20 @@ function M.init_pager()
   local _, sect, err = pcall(parse_ref, ref)
   vim.b.man_sect = err ~= nil and sect or ''
 
-  if not fn.bufname('%'):match('man://') then -- Avoid duplicate buffers, E95.
-    vim.cmd.file({ 'man://' .. fn.fnameescape(ref):lower(), mods = { silent = true } })
+  local man_bufname = 'man://' .. fn.fnameescape(ref):lower()
+
+  -- Raw manpage into (:Man!) overlooks `match('man://')` condition,
+  -- so if the buffer already exists, create new with a non existing name.
+  if vim.fn.bufexists(man_bufname) == 1 then
+    local new_bufname = man_bufname
+    while vim.fn.bufexists(new_bufname) == 1 do
+      new_bufname = new_bufname .. '_copy'
+    end
+    vim.cmd.file({ new_bufname, mods = { silent = true } })
+  else
+    if not fn.bufname('%'):match('man://') then -- Avoid duplicate buffers, E95.

comment_data.body:
the name is a uri. how about something like this: `man://?dedup=1`, `man://?dedup=2`

```suggestion
      new_bufname = man_bufname .. '?dedup=' .. tostring(i)
```

+    local new_bufname = man_bufname
+    while vim.fn.bufexists(new_bufname) == 1 do
+      new_bufname = new_bufname .. '_copy'

comment_data.body:
idk if `dedup` is the right nonce. I think typically something like `nocache` would be used, but that isn't intuitive for users. `new` seems good.
```suggestion
      new_bufname = man_bufname .. '?new=' .. tostring(i)
```

comment_data.body: From a user perspective `new` seems to be the most user-friendly designation.

comment_data.body:
nit (untested). for style, but also to avoid infinite loop.
```suggestion
    local new_bufname = man_bufname
    for i = 1, 100 do
        if vim.fn.bufexists(new_bufname) == 0 then
            break
        end
        new_bufname = ('%s?new=%s'):format(man_bufname, i)
    end
    vim.cmd.file({ new_bufname, mods = { silent = true } })
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -639,8 +639,20 @@ function M.init_pager()
   local _, sect, err = pcall(parse_ref, ref)
   vim.b.man_sect = err ~= nil and sect or ''
 
-  if not fn.bufname('%'):match('man://') then -- Avoid duplicate buffers, E95.
-    vim.cmd.file({ 'man://' .. fn.fnameescape(ref):lower(), mods = { silent = true } })
+  local man_bufname = 'man://' .. fn.fnameescape(ref):lower()
+
+  -- Raw manpage into (:Man!) overlooks `match('man://')` condition,
+  -- so if the buffer already exists, create new with a non existing name.
+  if vim.fn.bufexists(man_bufname) == 1 then
+    local new_bufname = man_bufname
+    local i = 1
+    while vim.fn.bufexists(new_bufname) == 1 do
+      new_bufname = man_bufname .. '?new=' .. tostring(i)
+      i = i + 1
+    end
+    vim.cmd.file({ new_bufname, mods = { silent = true } })

comment_data.body: Should we define a safe behavior if new buffers exceed the 100 ceiling? Even if that behavior is just to avoid resulting in E95, since there were no changes to the way we avoid said error.

comment_regular_data.body: I will be updating the functional tests tomorrow, to support the `?new=` designation. For lint, all i need to do is lower case 'Fix'?
For `lintcommit`, yes (and provide a scope). For `lint`, you can start with `make formatlua` -- but the linters report actual issues beside formatting.
If squash is intended, what would be the safest way to squash it in this repo? The answer to this question will confirm how to fix the lintcommit fail currently present in the pipeline.
squash is intended. are you going to finish this?

title: fix(man.lua): E95 when raw manpage content is piped into :Man
